BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: A lot of new snow to low altitudes: Large and very large dry avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The wind will be moderate to strong adjacent to ridgelines especially in the regions that are exposed to the foehn wind. In particular in gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain as well as above the tree line further wind slabs will form.
The large quantity of fresh snow as well as the wind slabs can be released naturally in all aspects. In particular in the regions with a lot of snow large and, in isolated cases, very large dry avalanches are possible. This applies especially in case of releases originating from starting zones that still retain some snow.
Including in starting zones in which avalanches have already been released natural avalanches, capable of reaching a long way, must be expected.
It is inadvisable to engage in ski touring, freeriding and snowshoe hiking outside marked and open pistes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 70 to 90 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Saturday. In all altitude zones a very large amount of snow is lying.
As a consequence of snowfall and the wind, fresh snow drift accumulations formed during the last three days. In isolated cases new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust.
Towards its surface, the snowpack is weak. The new snow of the last few days remains prone to triggering in all aspects.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will not decrease for the time being.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: A lot of snow has fallen over a wide area. Not yet all starting zones have released the snow entirely.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and wind, wind slabs formed since Saturday in gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. The large quantity of fresh snow as well as the sometimes deep wind slabs can be released naturally in all aspects.
In particular in starting zones where no previous releases have taken place and at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large dry avalanches are possible. Avalanches can occur again, even in paths where avalanches have already been released.
Ski touring and other off-piste activities, including snowshoe hiking, call for extensive experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
A lot of snow is lying in all altitude zones. Over a wide area over a wide area 60 to 80 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Saturday.
Over a wide area new snow is lying on a hard crust. The new snow of the weekend has settled to a large extent in particular on sunny slopes and at low and intermediate altitudes.
As a consequence of snowfall and the southerly wind, fresh snow drift accumulations formed at the weekend.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The meteorological conditions will cause a gradual decrease in the avalanche danger.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Slab avalanches and loose snow avalanches are still possible in particular during the day.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The wind will be moderate to strong at times especially in the regions exposed to the foehn wind. In gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain as well as above the tree line further wind slabs will form.
Above the tree line and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain the avalanche situation is dangerous.
In particular in starting zones where no previous releases have taken place and in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation medium-sized and large dry avalanches are possible. They can occur naturally.
It is inadvisable to engage in ski touring, freeriding and snowshoe hiking outside marked and open pistes. Ski touring and other off-piste activities, including snowshoe hiking, call for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 40 to 60 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Saturday. A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes.
In some places new snow is lying on a hard crust. As a consequence of rising temperatures and solar radiation the snowpack settled.
Weak layers exist in the old snowpack. In addition wind slabs formed in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will decrease gradually.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs in high Alpine regions. In particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation the wind slabs will increase in size additionally. Gliding avalanches can be released at any time of day or night.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh snow and the large wind slabs represent the main danger. As a consequence of the new snow slab avalanches are possible, even very large ones in isolated cases.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack will be unstable in particular on steep northeast, north and northwest facing slopes. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded still only poorly with the old snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs in high Alpine regions. In particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation the wind slabs will increase in size additionally.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The large quantity of fresh snow and the wind slabs formed by the strong southeasterly wind are poorly bonded with the old snowpack, also in all aspects on steep slopes. The avalanches can occur again, even in paths where avalanches have already been released.
As a consequence of a gathering strong northerly wind, clearly visible wind slabs will form in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas as well as above approximately 2200 m. In particular at intermediate and high altitudes the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase.
Wind slabs can especially at their margins be released, even by a single winter sport participant. The avalanches can in many cases reach medium size.
Fresh wind slabs are to be avoided in steep terrain. Whumpfing sounds serve as an alarm sign. Backcountry touring and other off-piste activities call for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger.
Small and medium-sized natural avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
50 to 70 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen above approximately 1800 m. The new snow is poorly bonded with the old snowpack. Caution is to be exercised on wind-protected shady slopes. Towards its surface, the snowpack is unfavourably layered and its surface consists of surface hoar, this also applies on steep sunny slopes. Towards its surface, the snowpack is unfavourably layered and its surface has a melt-freeze crust that is strong in many cases.
A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The danger of dry avalanches will decrease gradually. The northerly wind will transport the new snow and, in some cases, old snow as well.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow can be released easily or naturally in all aspects above approximately 1800 m. The solar radiation will give rise as the day progresses to rapid softening of the snowpack over a wide area especially at intermediate altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The snowpack will be prone to triggering in particular on wind-loaded slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: A clear night will be followed in the early morning by sometimes favourable conditions generally, but the danger of wet and gliding avalanches will increase later.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and wet snow represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a gathering strong northerly wind, clearly visible wind slabs will form in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas as well as above approximately 2200 m. In particular at intermediate and high altitudes the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase. They can especially at their margins be released, even by a single winter sport participant. The avalanches can in many cases reach medium size.
Fresh wind slabs are to be avoided in steep terrain. Whumpfing sounds serve as an alarm sign. Backcountry touring and other off-piste activities call for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger.
Small and medium-sized natural avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
20 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen above approximately 1500 m. The new snow is poorly bonded with the old snowpack. Caution is to be exercised on wind-protected shady slopes. Towards its surface, the snowpack is unfavourably layered and its surface consists of surface hoar,, also on steep sunny slopes. Towards its surface, the snowpack is unfavourably layered and its surface has a melt-freeze crust that is strong in many cases.
A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will persist. The northerly wind will transport the new snow and, in some cases, old snow as well.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow and wind slabs of the last few days represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh snow as well as the wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular at the base of rock walls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain above approximately 1800 m and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. In all aspects large and, in isolated cases, very large avalanches are possible. Single snow sport participants can release avalanches.
Snow slides and natural avalanches are still possible. This applies in particular in steep rocky terrain.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: 20 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen. In the last few days sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs formed. In addition the sometimes new snow-covered wind slabs must be taken into account.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be partly cloudy.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Large quantities of fresh snow and the wind-drifted snow can be released by a single winter sport participant in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2200 m. Avalanches can reach medium size. The prevalence of the avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. As a consequence of solar radiation more loose snow avalanches are to be expected as the day progresses, in particular medium-sized ones.

Avalanches can also be triggered in the old snowpack. Avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m. Places where surface hoar has been covered with snow are especially unfavourable. Avalanches can reach large size in isolated cases.
In addition small to medium-sized gliding avalanches and wet snow slides are possible, in particular on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2600 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided as far as possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The new snow and wind slabs of the weekend are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes above approximately 2200 m. The new snow of the last few days is lying on surface hoar in particular on wind-protected shady slopes above approximately 2400 m. The solar radiation will give rise as the day progresses to gradual moistening of the snowpack in particular on steep sunny slopes at intermediate and high altitudes. As a consequence of rising temperatures and solar radiation a crust formed on the surface, in particular on steep sunny slopes in all altitude zones.

Faceted weak layers exist in the centre of the old snowpack in particular on west, north and east facing slopes. This applies above approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The fresh wind slabs remain prone to triggering in particular on shady slopes at elevated altitudes. More gliding avalanches are to be expected.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Large quantities of fresh snow and the wind-drifted snow of Sunday can be released easily in all aspects above the tree line. Avalanches can reach large size in isolated cases. The prevalence of the avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude. Caution is to be exercised in particular on steep shady slopes, as well as adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation numerous loose snow avalanches are to be expected as the day progresses, in particular medium-sized ones. In addition medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large gliding avalanches and wet snow slides are possible, in particular on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area 30 to 50 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen above approximately 1600 m. The wind was storm force in some cases. Fresh wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes above the tree line. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to gradual moistening of the snowpack in particular on steep sunny slopes at intermediate and high altitudes. The new snow and wind slabs of the weekend are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes above approximately 2200 m. The solar radiation will give rise as the day progresses to gradual moistening of the snowpack in particular on steep sunny slopes at intermediate and high altitudes. As a consequence of rising temperatures and solar radiation a crust formed on the surface, in particular on steep sunny slopes in all altitude zones.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The fresh wind slabs remain prone to triggering in particular on shady slopes at elevated altitudes. More gliding avalanches and wet snow slides are to be expected.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new snow of the weekend represents the main danger. This snow is to be evaluated with care and prudence in all aspects above the tree line. The new snow can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects above the tree line. The off-piste conditions are to some extent critical. Temporary safety measures may be necessary.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area 30 cm of snow, and up to 50 cm in some localities, will fall until the early morning above approximately 1800 m. The covering of new snow is soft. The new snow can be released easily or naturally in all aspects above the tree line.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The snowpack will be in most cases moist. Gliding avalanches can be released at any time of day or night.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Individual, then as a consequence of solar radiation more, and in some cases even medium-sized, gliding avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2000 m. As a consequence of mild temperatures and solar radiation the snowpack can not consolidate.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2200 m. The prevalence of the avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude. Mostly avalanches are medium-sized. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation loose snow avalanches are to be expected as the day progresses, but they will be mostly small.

In addition a certain danger of gliding avalanches exists, in particular on steep sunny slopes at intermediate and high altitudes. These can in isolated cases reach medium size. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided as far as possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Fresh wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes above approximately 2200 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The fresh wind slabs remain prone to triggering at elevated altitudes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wet snow represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of warming during the day, the likelihood of wet avalanches being released will increase gradually in all regions. In all aspects small and medium-sized avalanches are possible. Gliding avalanches are possible. Avalanches can as before be released, in particular by large loads.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
A lot of rain has fallen over a wide area.
The weather conditions gave rise to moistening of the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be partly cloudy.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The old snowpack will be generally moist.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The meteorological conditions will foster a gradual weakening of the snowpack as the day progresses.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Moist snow slides and avalanches are possible in isolated cases.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As the moisture increases individual mostly small wet snow slides and avalanches are possible. Above approximately 1900 m and in gullies and bowls the danger of moist and wet avalanches is a little higher. This applies in particular on sunny slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack remains quite favourable. Below approximately 1600 m hardly any snow is lying. The fresh and older wind slabs are to be found especially in gullies and bowls and at high altitudes. Slow warming: These weather conditions will give rise to gradual moistening of the snowpack in particular on sunny slopes.
